title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that diminishing marginal returns begin after the fifth worker and/or does not explain that the marginal product (MP) of the sixth worker (12) was less than the MP of the fifth worker (15).
The response states that diminishing marginal returns begin after the fifth worker and explains that the marginal product (MP) of the sixth worker (12) was less than the MP of the fifth worker (15).

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the marginal revenue product of the fifth worker as $75 and/or does not show the work.

MRP = P × MP=$5 × 15=$75 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4BEB@

The response calculates the marginal revenue product of the fifth worker as $75 and shows the work.

MRP = P × MP=$5 × 15=$75 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4BEB@

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that 7 workers will be hired to maximize its profit and/or does not explain that the marginal revenue product (MRP) of the 7th worker ($50) is greater than the marginal resource cost (MRC) or wage ($24), but the MRP of the 8th worker ($20) is less than the MRC ($24).

The response states that 7 workers will be hired to maximize its profit and explains that the marginal revenue product (MRP) of the 7th worker ($50) is greater than the marginal resource cost (MRC) or wage ($24), but the MRP of the 8th worker ($20) is less than the MRC ($24).

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does none of the following:

· States that the marginal factor cost for the firm will decrease and explains that a decrease in the price of retail goods will lead to a decrease in demand for workers in that market, which will decrease the market wage and therefore decrease the firm’s marginal factor cost because the firm is a wage taker.

· States that the marginal revenue product curve for the firm will shift to the left and explains that the marginal revenue product is the price of the product times the marginal product, so a decrease in the market price of retail goods will decrease the marginal revenue product for every unit of labor.

The response does one of the following:

· States that the marginal factor cost for the firm will decrease and explains that a decrease in the price of retail goods will lead to a decrease in demand for workers in that market, which will decrease the market wage and therefore decrease the firm’s marginal factor cost because the firm is a wage taker.

· States that the marginal revenue product curve for the firm will shift to the left and explains that the marginal revenue product is the price of the product times the marginal product, so a decrease in the market price of retail goods will decrease the marginal revenue product for every unit of labor.

The response does both of the following:

· States that the marginal factor cost for the firm will decrease and explains that a decrease in the price of retail goods will lead to a decrease in demand for workers in that market, which will decrease the market wage and therefore decrease the firm’s marginal factor cost because the firm is a wage taker.

· States that the marginal revenue product curve for the firm will shift to the left and explains that the marginal revenue product is the price of the product times the marginal product, so a decrease in the market price of retail goods will decrease the marginal revenue product for every unit of labor.
